results.headline: 500 Days in a Cave, the Safest Refuge
results.summary_short: “No Place on Earth,” a documentary by Janet Tobias, recounts the experiences of Ukrainian Jews who literally went underground to escape the Nazis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Place on Earth

results.headline: Another Jaded Generation of Bright Young Things
results.summary_short: Alexandra McGuinness’s “Lotus Eaters” are pretty, rich and aimless, but they sure have nice digs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lotus Eaters

results.headline: A Radical Beatified
results.summary_short: “Free Angela and All Political Prisoners” is Shola Lynch’s documentary about the scholar and activist Angela Davis and her 1972 murder trial.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Angela & All Political Prisoners

results.headline: Washed-Up Artist Meets His Dark Muse
results.summary_short: “Eddie: The Sleepwalking Carnival,” a horror comedy from Boris Rodriguez, centers on a once-famous artist whose creative fires are stoked by his houseguest’s very strange habits.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eddie: The Sleepwalking Cannibal

results.headline: A Photographer Is Uneasy in Front of the Camera
results.summary_short: “Bert Stern: Original Mad Man” is Shannah Laumeister’s profile of the photographer she met at 13 and whose muse she would eventually become.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bert Stern, Original Madman

results.headline: Beware of the Man on the Couch
results.summary_short: In “6 Souls,” a psychiatrist tries to figure out what’s going on with a patient who has an unusual contingent of multiple personalities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 6 Souls

results.headline: Some Dessert, After That Meal With Wally
results.summary_short: Cindy Kleine’s gripping documentary about her husband, the theater director André Gregory, feels almost like a sequel to “My Dinner With André.”
results.display_title: Andre Gregory: Before and After Dinner

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Andre Gregory: Before and After Dinner

results.headline: Disco and Villains in 1983 Bollywood
results.summary_short: “Himmatwala” is a remake of a Bollywood disco film from 30 years ago.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Himmatwala

results.headline: Charisma, Wealth, Flattery. How Can She Resist?
results.summary_short: In “Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor,” a moralizing film directed by Tyler Perry, a bored wife succumbs easily to the blandishments of a wealthy man.
results.display_title: Tyler Perry's Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor

results.headline: For a Musician, Life Was a Song
results.summary_short: Francisca Gavilán plays the lead in “Violeta Went to Heaven,” about the Chilean musician and artist Violeta Parra.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Violeta Went to Heaven

results.headline: Fans Possessed by ‘The Shining’
results.summary_short: In “Room 237,” movie buffs pick apart Stanley Kubrick’s “The Shining,” finding references to the Holocaust and Apollo 11, among others.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Room 237

results.headline: A Muse to the Father, and a Wife to the Son
results.summary_short: “Renoir,” directed by Gilles Bourdos, tells the story of this Impressionist painter’s last model, who became the wife of his son Jean, the film director.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Renoir

results.headline: Lost: Man’s Best Friend
results.summary_short: The tale of a man, played by Jack Plotnick, in search of his missing dog, Paul, from the maker of the killer-tire classic, “Rubber.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wrong

results.headline: Old Enough to See the Glass as Half-Full
results.summary_short: Children in India campaign for a proper water-delivery system in “Revolutionary Optimists.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Revolutionary Optimists

results.headline: Good Intentions, Paving the Usual
results.summary_short: “The Place Beyond the Pines,” set in and around Schenectady, N.Y., is a tripartite tale in which the sins of the fathers are visited upon the sons.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Place Beyond the Pines

results.headline: Dealing With a Lot, and Nothing at All
results.summary_short: In “Somebody Up There Likes Me” a young man with little ambition has two constants in his life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Somebody Up There Likes Me

results.headline: Fighting the Peacenik Alien Within Her
results.summary_short: In “The Host” Saoirse Ronan seeks refuge from an alien race that has transformed most of the human population into smiling peaceniks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Host

results.headline: The Nanny Arrives; Eccentricity Is Squared
results.summary_short: In “Mental” a hitchhiker helps a man raise his troubled daughters after their mother is committed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mental

results.headline: The Joes Fight the Power
results.summary_short: Noise and heavy weaponry are major players in this follow-up to “G.I. Joe: Rise of the Cobra.”

results.headline: Is Domestic Bliss Too Much to Ask?
results.summary_short: Olesya Rulin stars in “Family Weekend,” a comedy about a high school athlete who tries to make her family “normal.”
